si.t: If a snake falls o[n top of a m]an who is litigating – his lawsuit will be long.
If a snake falls o[n top of a man who is litigat]ing – his lawsuit will be extremely protracted.
Wenn eine Schlange a[uf einen Ma]nn fällt, der [einen Rechtstreit füh]rt: Dieser Rechtstreit wird lange andauern.
According to KAL 1, p. 3, SU 51/49+ cannot be considered “canonical, but are merely very close to the canonical series (cf. ibd, p. 6, n. 57).

r.t: “to be hostile, to start a lawsuit”, “to bring suit and complain against” (CAD G: 61-62). The translation “who is litigating” is borrowed from

si.t: If a snake falls on top of a man who is engaged in a lawsuit and his lawsuit is long, the man […] will be used up.
If a snake falls onto a man who has been engaged in a protracted lawsuit – that lawsuit will be settled.
Wenn eine Schlange auf einen Mann fällt, der einen (schon) lang andauernden Rechtsstreit hat: Dieser Rechtstreit wird abgeschlossen werden.

r.t: “will be used up”, which probably wants to indicate a negative apodosis.
in the variation was chosen to make sense of the accusative

si.t: If a snake hisses and falls onto a man who is litigating – his adversary will supplicate him.
If [a snake] falls on top of man who is engaged on a lawsuit […], his […] will supplicate him.

r.t: 2 follows the line count in KAR. That copy suggests blank lines in a large breakage, moving the line count in column ii down by two lines compared to the opposite column i (see appendix).

si.t: The reason for this might be that DIŠ is missing where there should be one to start the line.

Another reason for the line count might stem from the fact that, from Omen 23.5 onwards, the line count fits the numbers of the Omina, VAT 10481+.1 ii 5 coinciding with Omen 23.5, VAT 10481+.1 ii 6 with Omen 23.6 etc.
By Omen 23.11, however, the numbers do not line up anymore.

r.t: In the score, the placement of the line break in VAT 10481+.1 between
is random. It does not indicate how long the breaks are.
does neither exist in the KAR copy nor in the copy of KAL 1 9. It might be a copy-paste mistake from SU 51/49+ ii 19.
If a snake falls onto a man who is being thrown into prison – that man will come out of prison; [that man: (his)

si.t: If a snake falls on top of a man who has been thrown in prison, that man will go [out] from prison.

r.t: If a snake falls onto a man who is being thrown into prison – that man will come out of his prison and

si.t: Wenn eine Schlange auf einen Mann, der in Haft einsitz, fällt: Der Mann wird aus seiner Haft herauskommen und … .

r.t: 2 places SU 51/49+ ii 20 in Omen 23.4* and SU 51/49+ ii 21 in Omen 23.5*.

si.t: VAT 10523+.2 has a different order here. This is VAT 10523+.2 ii 6 instead of ii 4. VAT 10523+.2 ii 4 is in Omen 23.5, ii 5 in 23.6, and ii 7 only in 23.9.
If a snake bites a man who is litigating [his adversary will supplic]ate him.
If a snake bites a man who is engaged in a lawsuit […]
If a snake bites a man who is litigating – ditto (his adversary will supplicate him).

Placing SU 51/49+ with Omen 23.5 instead of 23.6 and reading it [... EN INIM-šú uš-te-mi]-iq-šú is confirmed by ŠU.BI.AŠ.ÀM in VAT 10523+.2 ii 4 as VAT 10523+.2 ii 3 (Omen 23.3) has EN INIM-šú uš-te-me-eq-šú.
VAT 10523+.2 is the only large Middle Assyrian tablet for snake omens. Many of these omens can be placed with Neo Assyrian standard omens of šumma ālu.
Notably, the beginning of VAT 10523+.2 ii 4 is syntactically more individual.

r.t: Antecendet texts are in discussion. Without a colophone marking the corpus (
), it is not certain what the omens actually are.
F.i., Leichty did not see a connection to MA texts for Tablet 7 of
, but De Zorzi ascertained that they were actually really close (cf. De Zorzi 2014: 229). These texts are often difficult to date.

si.t: If a snake hisses and b[i]tes a man who is litigating – ditto (his adversary will supplicate him).
If a snake chatters and […] a man who is engaged in a lawsuit, there will be […] for him.

r.t: 's reconstruction is that it places SU 51/49+ ii 22 with this omen.

si.t: This circumstance is also the reason why our 23.6 is not the same as If a City's 23.6*.

r.t: The commentary texts BM 129092 and SpTU 5 259 (identical) contain commentaries on omens from Tablet 22 in its first and on omens from Tablet 23 in its second section. BM 129092, line 27:
, which means to twitter, said of a bird (quotation from Nabnītu IX 48 or 49 ?), and bird
means shout, said of a bird (quotation from unknown source)” (

si.t: If a snake hisses and frightens a man – illness will afflict hi[m ...]; that [ma]n: the hand will take hold of him.
If a snake chatters and frightens a man, illness will afflict him.
If a snake stares at a man on a holiday – worry, unhappiness for the man [...].
If a snake sees a man on a holiday – trouble; it will not be happy; […] for the man; the hand (of a god) will affect that man.

r.t: The glossary for KAL 1 reads NU DÙG.GA UZU as
in STT 65:20 (hymn to Nabû), CAD ṭ: 120a)

si.t: If a snake stares at a man and he kills it – his fears will not touch that man, that snake took its evil away.
If a snake sees a man and he kills it, misfortunes will not approach that man; that snake, evil […].
This is a positive omen containing the sign GAZ "to kill" in the protasis and ḪUL "evil" in the apodosis, both words with negative connotations.
Maybe a case of negative plus negative makes a positive.

If a snake stares at a man and scares him, so that (the man) tramples on its head and is afraid (of the snake) – loss of grain (but) that man will appease Marduk and he will be well, he will experience good fortune.
If a snake sees a man and frightens him and he tramples its head and it thrashes (about) – loss of grain; Marduk will care for that man, and it will be good; he will experience good fortune.

If a snake stares at a man and scares him, [so that (the man) tramples on its head and] is very afraid (of the snake) – lo[ss of grain] (but) that man will appea[se] Marduk [and he will be wel]l, he will exper[ience] good fortune.

Wenn eine Schlange einen Mann anschaut und ihn (dadurch) erschreckt [und er dann auf ihren Kopf tritt und sich sehr (vor der Schlange) ängstigt: Verlust von Getreide], / diesen Mann wird Marduk gesund se[in lassen und es wird ihm gut gehen, Gutes wird er erfahren].
[I]f a snake stares at a man and scares him, or he tramples on its head and is afraid (of the snake) – loss of grain (but) that man will appease Marduk and he will experience good fortune.

[W]enn eine Schlange einen Mann anschaut und ihn erschreckt, oder er auf ihren Kopf tritt und sich dann sehr (vo der Schlange) ängstigt: Verlust von Getriede, / diesen Mann wird Marduk gesund sein lassen und er wird Gutes erfahren.
The translation "that man will apease Marduk" follows the interpretation by Jiménez (CCP 3.5.33.A.b: 31).
ZI.GA is translated as "loss" without the alternative "claim" because the apodosis seems to imply that a negative situation is turned into a positive one by appealing to Marduk.
If a snake falls from above onto a man’s leg – a mortally ill person will die in the man’s house, the master of that house will experience misery and (then) he will die.
If a snake falls from above onto a man’s leg, a mortally ill person will die in the man’s house; the owner of that house will experience difficulty.
If a snake falls from above onto a man’s leg – [a mortally ill person will die] in that man’s house, [the mast]er of the house will experience misery and (then) he will d[ie].

r.t: In the commentary for A 0453+ in KAL 1, p. 50, the translation "from above" for
is said to be justified by the parallel

si.t: If a snake falls on top of a man who is lit[igating, bu]t his lawsuit is already dragging on – [his lawsuit] will be settled.
The reconstruction of di-in-šú instead of DI BI for the main variant is in accordance with 23.1.
